msItem.author: Hyginus
msItem.title: De astronomia
msItem.explicit: descendens CCCLXV dies suo cursu transigit.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: Verse ending of Hyginus
msItem.incipit: Terminat hyginus uolumen doctus moderans et
msItem.explicit: Tunc possim uisione dei giuari qui bene regnat.

msItem.author: Ps. Priscianus
msItem.title: De sideribus
msItem.incipit: Ad boreae partes arcti uertuntur et anguis
msItem.explicit: Celsior his saturnus tardior omnibus astris.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: Sententia Abbonis de differentia circuli et sperae
msItem.incipit: Studiosis astrologiae primo sciendum est
msItem.explicit: Si uero mota est aliquis planetarum est.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: Untitled
msItem.incipit: Denique luna totius zodiaci signa partes studioso lectori manifestabit
msItem.explicit: similiter de reliquis.
msItem.decoNote: 31v diagram of the motion of the moon and its phases.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: Domine Deus omnipotens sancta trinitas
msItem.explicit: et aliis ministrate ualeamus. Per.

msItem.title: On the creation of the luminaries according to the bible
msItem.incipit: Sancta scriptura nobis a deo per beatum moysen
msItem.explicit: luminare minus ut praeesset nocti.

msItem.title: De duodecim signis
msItem.rubric: De XII signis primitus de ariete
msItem.incipit: Regionem XII caeli in quam sol cursum suum dirigit
msItem.explicit: sed christus dominus saluator mundi euertit.

msItem.author: Cicero
msItem.title: Aratea
msItem.incipit: A quibus hinc subter possis cognoscere fultum
msItem.explicit: Hanc autem totam properant depellere pisces.

msItem.title: De signis caelis
msItem.incipit: Aries habet stellam in capite I
msItem.explicit: Anticanis eo quod contraria sit cani.
msItem.note: By Perseus placed the section about Hercules;

msItem.decoNote: Illustrations of the constellations; Triangulus left as draft, faintly marked; Virgiliae, Lyra and the Planets not executed. Stars marked with red dots. For detailed iconographical discussion see Sternbilder des Mittelalters and the entry in the Saxl Project.

msItem.rubric: De concordia solaris cursus et lunaris
msItem.incipit: Nouem horis in luna pro quinque diebus in sole
msItem.explicit: cum V diebus solaribus concordare.

msItem.incipit: Luna lucere dodrantis semuncias dicitur
msItem.explicit: IIII horas lucet luna V.

msItem.incipit: Unius semper horae dodrante et semuntia transmissa
msItem.explicit: tardius ueniret, tardiusque recederet.

msItem.author: Pliny the Elder
msItem.title: De presagiis tempestatum
msItem.note: Possibly taken from Libri computi, Lib. V, 12.
msItem.rubric: De presagiis tempestatum presagia solis XXVII
msItem.incipit: Purus oriens atque non feruens
msItem.explicit: relinquentia diras tempestates pronuntiant.

msItem.title: Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. VI, 4
msItem.rubric: Ambrosii Macrobii Theodosii de mensura et magnitudine terrae et circuli per quem solis iter est
msItem.incipit: In omni orbe uel sphera medietas centrum uocatur
msItem.explicit: et insuper centum LXX milia.

msItem.title: Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. VI, 5
msItem.rubric: Item eiusdem de mensura et magnitudine solis
msItem.incipit: His dictis quibus mensura quam terrae uel ambitus
msItem.explicit: Ergo ex his dicendum solem octies terra esse maiorem.

msItem.title: Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. VI, 6
msItem.incipit: Luna item circuli sui sex centesimam optinet portionem
msItem.explicit: circulum cencies maiorem esse tellure.

msItem.title: Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. VI, 7
msItem.incipit: Erathostenes philosophus idemque geometra subtilissimus
msItem.explicit: humanę coniecturae dimensionem admittit.

msItem.title: De positione et cursu septem planetarum (Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. V, 3)
msItem.rubric: De positione et cursu septem planetarum
msItem.incipit: Inter caelum et terram certis discreta spatiis VII sidera pendent
msItem.explicit: tum tardissime a trigesima luce ad easdem uices exit.

msItem.title: De intervallis earum (Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. V, 4)
msItem.incipit: Interualla earum a terra multi indagare temptarunt
msItem.explicit: ita VII tonis effici quam dyapason armoniam uocant.
msItem.decoNote: On f.53rb a diagram of planetary intervals ( Eastwood, Diagrams, p. 26).

msItem.title: De absidibus earum (Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. V, 5)
msItem.incipit: Tres autem quas supra solem diximus esse sitas occultantur
msItem.explicit: sicut in rotis radios ut subiecta figura demonstrat.
msItem.note: No accompanying drawing but space left for it.

msItem.title: De cursu earum per zodiacum circulum (Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. V, 6)
msItem.incipit: Cur autem magnitudines suas et colores mutent
msItem.explicit: sidera martis maxime inobseruabilis est cursus.

msItem.title: Excerpt from Libri computi, Lib. V, 11
msItem.incipit: A terra ad lunam tonum esse adnuntiant quod C¯X¯X¯V¯ stadiorum
msItem.explicit: Id est miliaria C¯V¯I¯I¯I¯I¯ et CCCLXXV.

msItem.author: Macrobius
msItem.note: Excerpt fromCommentarium in Ciceronis somnium Scipionis, Lib. II, 11, 5-17.
msItem.rubric: De mundano anno qui quindecim milibus solarium conficitur annorum Tullii Ciceronis somnium scipionis dictantis et Macrobii idem exponentis ac Senecae philosophorum auctoritas
msItem.incipit: Annus non is solus quem nunc communis omnium usus apellat
msItem.explicit: DLXXIII quisquis in digitos mittit inueniet.

msItem.note: Short texts on the relation between the solar and lunar path in the zodiac.

msItem.rubric: Incipit liber prognosticorum Arati prognostica solis et lune
msItem.incipit: Sol cum fuerit in ariete luna intrat (?) primam uidetur cum a sole disscenserit partibus x
msItem.explicit: In piscibus totidem quot in ariete partibus X simul eisdem a sole recesserit tunc apparebit.

msItem.incipit: Partes quot in die currit uerbi causa currit partes XII
msItem.explicit: aut amplius et quod erit uidebis quid faciat in XXXI.

msItem.author: Ptolemy
msItem.title: Preceptum canonis Ptolomei
msItem.incipit: Intellectus climatum polisepiseme requires
msItem.explicit: et addes aut deduces (69ra)

msItem.title: De nuptiis Philologiae et Mercurii. Book VIII. De astronomia
msItem.author: Martianus Capella
msItem.incipit: Quae dum geruntur et deorum sacer senatus
msItem.explicit: Consecutus autem radius intra XII partes eas opprimit et occultat.

msItem.note: Text on the abacus, added by a slightly later hand.
msItem.incipit: Numeri uidentur ratione formari et ex ipso naturaliter institui
msItem.explicit: etiam causam ignorans prouenire mirabitur.
msItem.bibl: Evans, G. R. "Schools and scholars: the study of the abacus in English schools c. 980–c. 1150." The English Historical Review 94 (1979): 71-89.

msItem.incipit: Titulus istę quattuor nomina dat auctori suo
msItem.explicit: idem mercurius intra XX momenta id est hoc supra solem intellege.

layout.p: Written for the most part in two columns, 33 lines.

origin.p: The manuscript was written in the last quarter of the tenth century, probably in the Abbey of Fleury. Evidence for this hypothesis is the mentioning of a certain Berno in the text of Abbo's Sententia (f.31rb). In the example illustrating the gap between new moon and the sun: Ita intellige ac si XII fratribus distet berno a suo abbate, Berno's name replaced that of 'Abbo' from the original version. If this is Berno, the future abbot of Reichenau, who came to study by Abbo in Fleury in 994, this would give us a possible date of origin.

The illustrations were made by the artist responsible also for the Ramsey Psalter (British Library, Harley MS 2904), a volume of Gregory's Homilies on Ezekiel (Orleans, Bibliothèque municipale, MS 175) and two Gospel books (New York, Piermont Morgan Library, M.827 and Boulogne-sur-mer, Bibliothèque municipale, Ms 11). It is uncertain if the artist was visiting Fleury and illustrated our manuscript there or the book was brought unfinished to England. One theory suggests that it the computistical-astronomical manual was prepared by Abbo himself for his teaching in Ramsey in 985. Since the connections between Fleury and England remained close, it is also possible that the manuscript was sent later over the Channel, after Abbo's return in Fleury in 987.

de Vyver, A. V. "Les œuvres inédites d’Abbon de Fleury." Revue Bénédictine 47 (1935): 125-169, here 142-144.
David Juste, ‘MS London, British Library, Harley 2506’ (update: 08.12.2017), Ptolemaeus Arabus et Latinus. Manuscripts, ptolemaeus.badw.de/ms/289.
Noel, W. G. The Making of B. L. Harley Mss. 2506 and 603 (unpublished doctoral dissertation, Cambridge University, 1992).
Holcomb, M. Pen and Parchment: Drawing in the Middle Ages. New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2009, p. 67-68.
